One ofthc best arranged and most useful


publications Of the kud that has fallen un-

TMQgc If R9chcaf,r." It is compiled by
Mr. Elisha NV, ANA contains ia d very com
pact and neat form, besides the usual iafor-
mation OF q Directory, a sketch Of the hista-
ry Of the village from 1912 to 1927; an en-.
gravcd map. and various fac +, statistical and
descriptive. The carries. permanent settle
ment in Rochester appears to Nave been
in 1899 or 10. Tie fl! child born there
was in MAY 4. 1910. In 1879. the prpscnt
site, then owned by Nathaniel Rochester,
VIM FitzbuiBh, and Charles Carrall, Of Ma
ryland, was surveyed into VILLAGE lots, open.


ed for sale, and the name Of Rochester, the
family name Of the senior proprietor, given
to it. The FIRST merchants store Was open
cd by Ira West, in 1912. at may tend to
give an idea, (says the work, of the COM
merciai and civil Importance OF this section
of the State at that time, to state that the
mail was then carried from Canandligua to
Haniord's Landing and tue nriChhorhood Of
Rochester, oucc q week, on horseback, and
part of the time by womani'' The first
mill, VITA four run Of stones, was erected in
1915. In December of that year, the census
was taken--.hc population 31l. The first
newspaper Cnow the Monroe Republican,
was established in 1916. The village was in
corporated i'll II. The contrast between that
and the present oonditic.. oil the village is vc


ry striking. ri the census in December
last, it contained 1909 inhabitants. Thirty
four mails arrive and depart each week
There are forty-two merchant stores, FIVE
hardware, druggist. ii boot and shoe. antl
IS OF other descriptions; and 1l3 rnauuftc-
t'>s:-a anu shops Of various kinds. Tea places
OF public worship. several of them large and
elegant structures; a court house, iai, and
market buildings, tQfcct hy so, erecting on

theatre. There are seven merchant -four.
ing mills, with 81 run Of stones, aud three
mills Tor custom work. with seven run of
stones ~ the foro'er i50,169 hbls. OF slour
! we're made during the year 1896. The Mill.

ries.-Arrangements are made tor erecting

that the rocky mountains may be passed
without any svrioHs inconvenience or expo.
sure, even in large parties. He left St.
l.cuis in March, and returned in September,
after having gone one hundred and fifty
miles down river on the other side, to the
Great Lake. He was seventy days on his
way home, and his horses and mules we're in
excellent ordcr.--Wagons could 80 the
whole distance; and grass, buffalo, and other
food tor man and beast were abundant
Subsistence might have been obtained every
day for one thousand men; and often tor ten
thousand. The great lake is about one hum
dred miles long. sixty or eighty wide, and
salter than the ocean. The route is by the
north Branch Of the Platte, and the course
of the Buenaventra.
ROCKY MOUNTAINS.

~It is a remarkable fact, that. in popua-
ton of nearly eight thousand. not one adult
person is a native of that village! The old.
est person now living, who was born there.
is nat yet seventeen years Of age! The pro.
gress of Rochester, altogether, is unexam-
pied, even in the history of the rapidly pop
ulatng settlements of the west

The following is an extract from a Bar
BADGES paper, of the 9th ut.--


/" The wharves exhibit now, the dulcst
scene which we ever remember to have OBJ
served at this period of the year. EXCEPT
from the few sugars shipping for England
it would appear as if trade and commerce
had entirely left us. The absence of the
American vessels, it must be confessed, has
made great difference in the appearance
Of things. The crop Of sugar this year will
fall miserably short; and, we apprehend,
that in several of the other islands, there
will be a great deficiency. In Antigua, we
have been informed, that not more than 60OO
hogsheads arc expected"

close OF the second day from neT seisu.Si
Mademoiselie D'Abi was pronounced by
the apothecary to be in iminent danger.-Dr'
MIS- opinion conceded but TOO perfectly with
that of his medical subaltern, and IN spite OF
their united endeavors to save the interesting
Young creature entrusted to their care, II
soon became evident that the hand Of ueath
was on her, and that human art was power
less to unioose that fatal grasp. Previous 20
her dissolution, she lay for many days IN
state of perfect stupor, far less painful to
contemplate than the previous delcrum,
during which she had talked incessantiy
with the embodied creatures OF her fancy,
rambling voub!y in her native tongue, and
now and then breaking out in snatches OF
wild songs or wilder laughter. But at last
that fearful mirth died away in faiuter and
fainter bursts, and broken syllables. and in
articulate sounds succeeded the voluble
speech like dyingmurmurs of a distant echo,
and "then," as tile nurse expressed it, "shc
Law as quite as lamb" for many, many
days with eyes half closed but not in slum-


brous torpor, the gentle harbinger of more
perfect rest.


Towards the close of the fourteenth day


OF Blanchc's illness, the respiration of the
unconscious suffe1er became quick and la


borious, and DR.. M. whose finger was on her
pulse, directed that the curtains OF her bed
should be drawn ASIDE, and free current OF
/ air admitted through the open Windows
/ Mr.. L. had entered with the physician,


and stationug himself at the beds foot, stood


there with folded II ms, and eyes fixed in sad


and hopeless contemplation on the affecting


object before him. Though the eyes OF
/ Blanche were more than haIf vcled by their
/ full, heavy lids, a streak Of soft blue was
I Still discernable through the Ions dark LASH


es, from whence, however, emanated no
spark of Intelligence; and far different from
| the finely blended rose-h hues OF hed!thtul


beauty, vas that Bright crimson which
burnt in ether cheek Her bead was rais-


ed little frcm the oiilow, by the supporting


arm of the nurse, Who, with her hand '.i'l


at liberty. put ASIDE the deep frill OF her cap,


and the d sold red lingtets which Id eA.


capped bcneati, it, that the sweet air might
visit with its comforting coolnesS tGosc


throbbing temples anA that burning brow.--


Ii was beautiful, mild, warm Aprh even


ing, redoent cf HE aud joy, and Nature !
) renovation, and the pale, golden light ut al
, April sunset penetrated even through Lon
don atmosphere, and amongst labyrinth q


high walls, and hlackcncd roofs, and cluster
ing chimneys, into the very chamber o


Blanche; and even to that confined chamber
!. and over those gloomy precincts, came the


soft breath OF Spring, breathing delicious


fragrance, As il was waited through hci
open windoN. over box Of migioncttc, coax


ed into early blossom by the assduous cher


iahing Of one who had watched over tnt


miniature garden WITH the Impatient intrrcs


OF eager childhood.


Y 'Ihe balmy air stole gently gradually ntt


the sick CHAMBER, and between .hr part


ed courtains of the bed as though il were ;


thing of Intelligence, aud came gladly OF


its blessed mission to convey to the dyiu!


Blanche the last soothing sensation sh'


might yet taste on earth. the odoroOs wait


ing of her favoritc flowcrs.-lt came not il


vain, as the caressing coolness played oNc'


her face, and when il had wandered a icN


moments amongst the parted rinslct:, hel


quick and laborious breathing became les
} and less distressing, and at lengtn, inhaling


one long and deep Inspiration, subsidel int,
regular and almost impcrccptibie nspra
ton, like that OF sleeping ntaut.


~ that moment, there struck up at the
! farther end Of neighhorng strret. a s.rait


ofwild music, from a band Of itlncraht mu
sicians, wandering Sayovards. VIVA ant
touching was the strain as il came mAlowet
) by distance, and mingled with the eycnin,
breeze. it Was al" Rams dcs NacaeS."-
10 every son and daughter of Hclyctla,
spirit stirring spell 4 magic melody uevc,
vet listened to unnostd by any wlnderc,
from her mountain land---oulv the iusensibl'


car at death. or Vi the tiyiug--but it secmct
, as If perception vet fingered 10 that q
Blanche. As the notes Of that national al,
, swelied out more and more distinctly,


slight tremor passed over her FEATURES ant
at last, as IT awakening from deep sleep
, her soft blue eyes perfectly uncloscd, aux
gIancmg upwards towards TIE female form
: OH whose bosom her head was pillowed, sh,
= mur'aurcd in her own native tongue "Man
: an bonne Mamanl"


I AS She uttered those few faltcring words
, her head SUM. lower upon that kind pillow
, like weary child, the fair eye-lds droppet
heavily over those soft blue orbs; but lonj


after their lustre was forever shrouled, ant
long after the beautiful lips were closed, an,


the last breath had escaped them in thos
: few touching words, the smile still liueeret
I there, with which those words were spoken
!, as il impressed by the parting rapture Of re
cogniticH with the Maternal SDilit, permit
, ted, possibly TO accompany the dark Ange
; on his aWlu mission, TO overcome his terror
by her looks OF heavenly wclcome. and re
ce!ying from his hands the new Celestial, i
towards which, even in their day. of morta
. probation, the pious Mother had "trainet
! up her child ia lhe way she should go.''

7ent-up load Of nnparticipat.d grief. Bat
'Eheodore's letter contained oneWrittcn III
different hand d-writing, and though the tears
of Blanche still fell as she pcrusc's those
characters, they were the last drops 0. tue
shower, through which a sunbeam was a'-
ready breaking. Upon the contents OF tn'e
packet she might have been said to i've ior
many wceks--for day after day her eyes iea
upon them, TIL one OF her little innocent o.
servers ask ed, in tone OF artlcss sYmpathy,
If she was not tired Of trying 70 learn an
that close long writing by heart, wh'ch hau
vexed her so much too, az the hrst rSa'i''s;


The second letters were rs eagerly alo
anxiously opened as tue former nav pecn'
Bur these were read with gllstelinS eyes on
iv will. tl,e -ekintled hight uf giadness
heamed on the Ingenious conntehance OF
BIancbe: and sometimes. in the midst OF
some tyentieth re -perusal, as if her heart
sought sympathy in the exubcrance OF ITS
happiness, she would catch up in her arms,
and halt smother with playful kisses, one
Of the wondering children---as ready, how
ever, at i.as. t. share the JOY ot their young
nsLructress. as to participate in her sorrows.
With these last letters came an ivory work.
box, an elegant oriental toy, lined with saii-
dal wood and fitted UP with many conpart-
fnents, each containing some Ingenious NICK :
uack-sone small tool of fairy workmanship,
fashioned for latly's hand, or some eXqul-
site essence in its FGc0H OF ghaed glass
contained in the same envelope directed by
her brother It was 4 delight to the inqnis-
tive children 70 pry over and over asaln,
INTO every drawer and compartment in this
beautiful box: audBlanche was too sweet tenn
yeretl to refuse Tie often ask ed indulgence, on
ly she watched with ielloIs care, lest their III.
lie busy fingers should njure any part Of the
delicate workmanship; and il Miss Criw-
ford was present, she resisted with evident
ANNOYANCE their opportunities to be allowed
to take out ot cunning secret drawer
(which had not long remained secret from
them) TWO beautitul little pictures" SO
beautiful" they said aud lone SO like
Na'amsele e''--That one was her brothers
miniature; and when they asked her If she
did not love him de4iiy ior sending her such
a tnc present, she smiitd and Olushed, and
simply answered, that She did Indeed dearly
love him. The little girls were not long in
discovering. moreover, that ;he return OF this
dear brother lad been announced in his
last letter The regiment was recalled &c
Europe. ana he wrote on the eve OF embark
ation.


It SO happened, that Oh lie evening when





its secret hoard Of gladncss, oh how long
had that poor heart been stranger to such
bissful feelinEsi--AIrs l.---.~'s circle was a
large and gay one, and proposal to form,
quadriles being suddenly made, ana as
promptly acceded to. Madsmosellc IS de-
tained to take her patient sitting at the pi-
uDo forte. She had always aCccdca with
willing sweetness TO similar reGuistlOn5, but
this evening she sat down to the instrument
with even joyous readiness, aud the cNnbc-
rance of her happiness found expression in
such sprightly measures, that her liking FIN
gers soon o1tstript the common time ot the
dancers, and many calls for moderation was
sent towards her from the scamperiug and
desparing performers. Then would she
laugh and blush, and shake her head in play
tul reproach AT her own lawless perform
ance. and for a whlle--a very little while
the restless fingers were restrained &c
slower movements: once or twice she look
cd towards the dancers, as il with vehem-
ent longing to spring mp and minglc in theii
gay evolu:ions; bat those glauccS were mo
Inentary, and her eyes dropped again upon
The very keys but such smiling and halt
txulting playiulncSs lurk "a about her mouth
as II she were anticipating some hour Of fu-
rure gladness, when she Should Join llaui:
s+ISC HiOtS Ht luC NSHNC Nlttl tiiN NOIll
panons Of her youth, On the carth--thl
lovely green sward, of her own dear ccun-
try.--NVhatever were the fond rcyervS oi
poor Blanche, it is certain that her musical
task was so unequaily performed THAI even
ing, as to cause much discontinue among
the dancers, at length despairingly mani.
rested in their relaxing eXertions, and il the
tedious, loungng pauses between the sets.


During one of these, a small knot OF gen
tlemen stood convcrsng with Mrs. L.
close to the piano-forte, on which, mnglc,
with music, books and manuscripts, lay sew.
eral pamphlets and newspapers. One oftht
gentlemen, carelessly glancing his eye uNei
the miscellaneous heap, caught up a paper
with suddenly excited interest, cXclaimug
'Ah here is already public account ut tle
melancholy occurrence, Of which my letter.
from Madras make mention" Then rapid
iy he read aloud the para graph which STATE
that, The Regiment, de Mehron being un-
der orders FOR Europe, had been safely EN-.
barked on board the Transports pro,d fol
irs reception, all but the last boat, CONSISTING
Of the Lieut.. Colonel, his lady and their fam.
lily, and two young officers Of the regiment
when by some Encouragement the boat wa.
suddenly upset in that tremendous surf, ant
notwithstanding the exertions ofthe native.
or their attending catamarans, every SOIL
persisted, except the wife and younges
daughter Of the colonel, and one Of the yount
officers, Lieut.. Albi."-Thcn followed
the names of those who had found a water,

~ Faithful Dog,"-We understand some
of the inhabitants in the vicinity of the
"mill dam" were awakened from sleep "a
bout l2 o'clock on Mondav night, by an unu-
sual barking OF dog Efforts we're made
TO rid themselves Of a troublesome disturber
of their slumbers, by killing the dog; and
while in the pursuit, they found his master
in deep hole near the dam, in which he had
fallen, and from which, on account Of the
sad effects of intemperance, he was unable
to cxtricate himself His faithful dog moan
cd by his side, and brought that relief with
out which his master might have pcrished

@AN Bu2dinS-Ihe Larch Trec..--A late
English paper mentions the arrival at Leith
OF the brig Betsey. from Drontheim, with
cargo Of boards This vessel is said to be
the identical one, then yatch, that bro't
over King William 20 England 1877 years
ago. The timber Of this vessel is the Greek
larch, Or, as it is called IN Mayence. where
it was planted more than two centuries
since, and where some fine forests are now
growing. Hackmetack 1t is the mos. dura-
ole timber ever made use Of in the construc-
ton .. vessels. This timber, if we mistake
iot, is ahln2ant in our forests, but has not
been esteemed of SO durable nature as ma
ny other kinds ui wood. Live oak is es-
teemcl superior. and the kind of oak. de-
nominated .Jersey pasture oak" if we mis-
take not, is also preferred for ship building.

THE VILLAGE OF ROCHESTER,.
full articles.article:
One ofthc best arranged and most useful


publications Of the kud that has fallen un-
der our observation is, ".Y Dirsct4rY for he
TMQgc If R9chcaf,r." It is compiled by
Mr. Elisha NV, ANA contains ia d very com
pact and neat form, besides the usual iafor-
mation OF q Directory, a sketch Of the hista-
ry Of the village from 1912 to 1927; an en-.
gravcd map. and various fac +, statistical and
descriptive. The carries. permanent settle
ment in Rochester appears to Nave been
in 1899 or 10. Tie fl! child born there
was in MAY 4. 1910. In 1879. the prpscnt
site, then owned by Nathaniel Rochester,
VIM FitzbuiBh, and Charles Carrall, Of Ma
ryland, was surveyed into VILLAGE lots, open.


ed for sale, and the name Of Rochester, the
family name Of the senior proprietor, given
to it. The FIRST merchants store Was open
cd by Ira West, in 1912. at may tend to
give an idea, (says the work, of the COM
merciai and civil Importance OF this section
of the State at that time, to state that the
mail was then carried from Canandligua to
Haniord's Landing and tue nriChhorhood Of
Rochester, oucc q week, on horseback, and
part of the time by womani'' The first
mill, VITA four run Of stones, was erected in
1915. In December of that year, the census
was taken--.hc population 31l. The first
newspaper Cnow the Monroe Republican,
was established in 1916. The village was in
corporated i'll II. The contrast between that
and the present oonditic.. oil the village is vc


ry striking. ri the census in December
last, it contained 1909 inhabitants. Thirty
four mails arrive and depart each week
There are forty-two merchant stores, FIVE
hardware, druggist. ii boot and shoe. antl
IS OF other descriptions; and 1l3 rnauuftc-
t'>s:-a anu shops Of various kinds. Tea places
OF public worship. several of them large and
elegant structures; a court house, iai, and
market buildings, tQfcct hy so, erecting on
the plan OF the new market in Boston, and a
theatre. There are seven merchant -four.
ing mills, with 81 run Of stones, aud three
mills Tor custom work. with seven run of
stones ~ the foro'er i50,169 hbls. OF slour
! we're made during the year 1896. The Mill.

are large stone structures of 5, 6 and 2 sto-
ries.-Arrangements are made tor erecting
two others during the ensuing summer with
II run OF stones. cotton factory is in op.
Grafton, with 1400 spindles and 80 power
looms, and employing SO youths and chill.
dren, and woollen factory. Six newspa.
peis are published in the village; one daily.
one semi-weekly, two weekly, one semi.
monthly, and one monthly. Three bridges
have been constructed over the Gennessee
river-oight canal basins-two dry docks


&c. The Directory gives tho following ia. .
bular view, as exhibiting the increase ofpop.
Il

full articles.headline: ROCKY MOUNTAINS.
full articles.article:
that the rocky mountains may be passed
without any svrioHs inconvenience or expo.
sure, even in large parties. He left St.
l.cuis in March, and returned in September,
after having gone one hundred and fifty
miles down river on the other side, to the
Great Lake. He was seventy days on his
way home, and his horses and mules we're in
excellent ordcr.--Wagons could 80 the
whole distance; and grass, buffalo, and other
food tor man and beast were abundant
Subsistence might have been obtained every
day for one thousand men; and often tor ten
thousand. The great lake is about one hum
dred miles long. sixty or eighty wide, and
salter than the ocean. The route is by the
north Branch Of the Platte, and the course
of the Buenaventra.

~It is a remarkable fact, that. in popua-
ton of nearly eight thousand. not one adult
person is a native of that village! The old.
est person now living, who was born there.
is nat yet seventeen years Of age! The pro.
gress of Rochester, altogether, is unexam-
pied, even in the history of the rapidly pop
ulatng settlements of the west

full articles.headline: WEST INDIA TRADE
full articles.article:
The following is an extract from a Bar
BADGES paper, of the 9th ut.--


/" The wharves exhibit now, the dulcst
scene which we ever remember to have OBJ
served at this period of the year. EXCEPT
from the few sugars shipping for England
it would appear as if trade and commerce
had entirely left us. The absence of the
American vessels, it must be confessed, has
made great difference in the appearance
Of things. The crop Of sugar this year will
fall miserably short; and, we apprehend,
that in several of the other islands, there
will be a great deficiency. In Antigua, we
have been informed, that not more than 60OO
hogsheads arc expected"

close OF the second day from neT seisu.Si
Mademoiselie D'Abi was pronounced by
the apothecary to be in iminent danger.-Dr'
MIS- opinion conceded but TOO perfectly with
that of his medical subaltern, and IN spite OF
their united endeavors to save the interesting
Young creature entrusted to their care, II
soon became evident that the hand Of ueath
was on her, and that human art was power
less to unioose that fatal grasp. Previous 20
her dissolution, she lay for many days IN
state of perfect stupor, far less painful to
contemplate than the previous delcrum,
during which she had talked incessantiy
with the embodied creatures OF her fancy,
rambling voub!y in her native tongue, and
now and then breaking out in snatches OF
wild songs or wilder laughter. But at last
that fearful mirth died away in faiuter and
fainter bursts, and broken syllables. and in
articulate sounds succeeded the voluble
speech like dyingmurmurs of a distant echo,
and "then," as tile nurse expressed it, "shc
Law as quite as lamb" for many, many
days with eyes half closed but not in slum-


brous torpor, the gentle harbinger of more
perfect rest.


Towards the close of the fourteenth day


OF Blanchc's illness, the respiration of the
unconscious suffe1er became quick and la


borious, and DR.. M. whose finger was on her
pulse, directed that the curtains OF her bed
should be drawn ASIDE, and free current OF
/ air admitted through the open Windows
/ Mr.. L. had entered with the physician,


and stationug himself at the beds foot, stood


there with folded II ms, and eyes fixed in sad


and hopeless contemplation on the affecting


object before him. Though the eyes OF
/ Blanche were more than haIf vcled by their
/ full, heavy lids, a streak Of soft blue was
I Still discernable through the Ions dark LASH


es, from whence, however, emanated no
spark of Intelligence; and far different from
| the finely blended rose-h hues OF hed!thtul


beauty, vas that Bright crimson which
burnt in ether cheek Her bead was rais-


ed little frcm the oiilow, by the supporting


arm of the nurse, Who, with her hand '.i'l


at liberty. put ASIDE the deep frill OF her cap,


and the d sold red lingtets which Id eA.


capped bcneati, it, that the sweet air might
visit with its comforting coolnesS tGosc


throbbing temples anA that burning brow.--


Ii was beautiful, mild, warm Aprh even


ing, redoent cf HE aud joy, and Nature !
) renovation, and the pale, golden light ut al
, April sunset penetrated even through Lon
don atmosphere, and amongst labyrinth q


high walls, and hlackcncd roofs, and cluster
ing chimneys, into the very chamber o


Blanche; and even to that confined chamber
!. and over those gloomy precincts, came the


soft breath OF Spring, breathing delicious


fragrance, As il was waited through hci
open windoN. over box Of migioncttc, coax

~ Faithful Dog,"-We understand some
of the inhabitants in the vicinity of the
"mill dam" were awakened from sleep "a
bout l2 o'clock on Mondav night, by an unu-
sual barking OF dog Efforts we're made
TO rid themselves Of a troublesome disturber
of their slumbers, by killing the dog; and
while in the pursuit, they found his master
in deep hole near the dam, in which he had
fallen, and from which, on account Of the
sad effects of intemperance, he was unable
to cxtricate himself His faithful dog moan
cd by his side, and brought that relief with
out which his master might have pcrished

@AN Bu2dinS-Ihe Larch Trec..--A late
English paper mentions the arrival at Leith
OF the brig Betsey. from Drontheim, with
cargo Of boards This vessel is said to be
the identical one, then yatch, that bro't
over King William 20 England 1877 years
ago. The timber Of this vessel is the Greek
larch, Or, as it is called IN Mayence. where
it was planted more than two centuries
since, and where some fine forests are now
growing. Hackmetack 1t is the mos. dura-
ole timber ever made use Of in the construc-
ton .. vessels. This timber, if we mistake
iot, is ahln2ant in our forests, but has not
been esteemed of SO durable nature as ma
ny other kinds ui wood. Live oak is es-
teemcl superior. and the kind of oak. de-
nominated .Jersey pasture oak" if we mis-
take not, is also preferred for ship building.
